reviewText: A timeless classic. Tons of mods, great physics, performance, stability and a lot of memories. Highly recommended for anyone interested in sim racing.\n\nAlso, get into an online league!

reviewText: My god, I am so glad this game has finally made its way onto steam! Before I played this game, I didn't care about racing sims. When my friend showed me this game however, I fell in love. It was the game that made me want to buy a race wheel.\nThis game is so much fun to play, the physics are great and the AI are very challenging. The thing that drew me, however, was the mods. This game has a HUUUUUGE selection of mods available, adding new cars and tracks ranging from a large number of different types. You can add movie cars, old F1 cars, dirt tracks, freaking trucks, even stupid stuff like horses and... a toilet car. Almost anything you can imagine has been modded at somepoint. I spent hours just playing just downloading mods and driving them around.\nSo long as you can look past the slighty outdated graphics, this is a great game to buy.

reviewText:

IF you are looking for modern graphical eye candy"

reviewText: I bought this game in 2005 and i've done thousands and thousands of laps driving mainly F1 cars. Even though it doesn't make proper use of the latest hardware and has dated graphics, it's still an awesome racing sim.\n\nFor those people that bought the game previously and want to add it to your Steam account without buying it again, just go to http://rf1comm.rfactor.net/purchase/get_steam_key.php and enter your rFactor order number with the email address that was used when purchasing rFactor. You will then be mailed a Steam key which can then be activated on Steam as per normal.

reviewText:
Thought I'd justify the well deserved attention it needs. It's going to be a lengthy one, but I reckon it's a worth while.
Here's a quick summary of what I will write (Split between Pros and Cons). Lengthy write up below.
Pros:
-Many 'completed' mods
-Still actively played
-Customisable
-Realfeel plugin (Best FFB ever), Especially with HistorX
-HistorX is a must play mod - The sound in the game is FABULOUS.
-Brings a smile :)
-Never too old, or tired
Cons:
-Need to create multiple rFactor files
-Complexity in dumping mods in files
-Not all are match-files friendly
-No more development in game
-Spend HOURS getting mods to work ( On many ocassions)
Recommended Mods :
-HistorX Touring Cars
-Honda NSX/Corvette C6
-Endurance Series (EnduRacers)
-GPC 1979

Lengthy write up:
Yes, it's a game a decade ago. Why not get rFactor 2, GSCE, AC? By no means, I'm saying you should buy just this 1 game and ignore the rest. If you could own all of them, get all. But if you had to decide on 1, this would be it.
This is literally multiple games for the price of 1. Mods like HistorX, GPC 1979, Endurance series, Honda NSX etc. In particular, games with realfeel plugin brings heaven to the game. I'd dare say particularly the HistorX mod has the best FFB in any sim. What's more they are free. No Pay-to-play DLCs. These Modders deserve the respect. Salute.

This game is highly associated to Stock Car Extreme (SCE) because it uses the same engine - Gmotor. Now SCE, undoubtly, is a game that I'd say stand a fair fight. Why did I put rFactor > SCE? Purely because of the 'finished'/'completed' feel of a game. Everything in rFactor feels right. Now be cautious, this game isn't meant to be played with its based game. You are supposed to play mods with it. And I highly recommend to play with mods with REALFEEL PLUGIN IN MIND FROM THE START" (as quoted by my friend). SCE is probably the most completed package as Reiza is constantly bringing new features
date: updates. This would be the 2 sims i'll get. Let say it this way
hoursPlayed: it's SCE as I find the game fundamentally good enough that it doesn't need mods. If you want MORE FUN
voteText: rFactor.\n\nI've been in SimRacing for 8 years now. I've played rFactor
votesFunny: followed the development of Assetto Corsa. I was borned into rFactor
commentsCount: as it was my first sim. Done league races and till today
column17: it still brings joy to me and excitement which many new titles struggle today. I've never had the surge to play the game again on the new modern titles.\n\nIn conclusion
column18: the price does sound ridiculous for a decade old game. But I still see the longevity in the game for the upcoming years. Easy to set-up dedicated host servers
column20: most of the mods are the definition of the current modern sims we have today. This game is the 'Metaphor Of the All Sims' being developed today. I'd rate this game 9.99/10 (the 0.01 for the awful default cars
column21: but see it as a perfect score ;) )\n"

reviewText:
Introduction:A thrilling racing simulator that is great for any racing fan. Unique cars and tracks make this a great adition to any racing fans library. This is still a very good racing simulator many years later. The graphics and effects aren't special but it gives you a good solid racing platform that includes what you need. This game has been out for quite some time which means a lot of mods have been created that make the game so much better. If you enjoy tandem drifting or drifting this is a must have for any drift sim player. The physics make it an unparalleled experience.

Pros:Good wheel support but requires quite some tweaking
Great community and pretty active player base
Classic track selection
Realistic physics that create great immersion
Difficulty and race environment options

Cons:Weak career or campaign mode
Very difficult control setups
Developer made cars without mods
Barely any tuning or customization

Conclusion:This is definitely a solid racing simulator. With the realistic physics and good wheel support this is a great game for any racing fan, espcially with a gaming wheel. If you're looking to play online with your friends or enjoy good quality racing sims this is a great choice.

For more reviews check out  Original Curators Group
voteText: 32 of 40 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've had this game for years, with a ton of community mods tracks and cars.  This is one of the best ever, it's a race sim not a arcade racer.
The good:
Stacks of community based addons
Fully customizable race options
Build your own seasons with the right third party tools or a text editor
24 hour real time clock with time compression multipliers. Start racing at night and finish in the afternoon
Variable levels of difficulty with driving aids, AI settings and damage mulitpliers
Great mulitplayer platform (i've only tried LAN with adding AI
AI cars are not great but not the worst, the cars aren't affected by damage and tyre wear the same way as a human driver.

The not so good:
A bit dated, I can run the graphics at full with 40 AI cars and seems to run fine
No Rain and or other weather effects. Not a biggy
There's better racing software out there, particularly for multi-player.  If you want multiplayer go Iracing it's pricey but constantly being developed and generally not a wreck fest.
Season and career play seems a little un-developed

In all a classic, I spent most of my sim-driving time on Iracing but come back to this one just love the rally cross tracks available and some old classic tracks not avialable anywhere else
voteText: 21 of 22 people (95%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
First things first, this game is old. 10 years old. Don't come expecting much in the way of graphics, you'll be disappointed. If you want graphics, go for a new sim like Assetto Corsa,

Second, the base game content sucks. If you don't like modding games, don't buy this game.

Third, this is damned fun. The AI is highly adaptable, I have found. None of the awkwardness of being too fast for one difficulty but too slow for the next one. The modding community is enormous, IE to scales I've only really seen beaten by Bethesda RPGs and FSX. Want F1 cars from 1982? Got that. Want Indycars from 1998? Got that too. Want Argentinian Touring Cars, Australian GT cars, or British Formula 3? It's got all that.

And, despite the game being 10 years old, the modding community is still active today. Mods for this year's Formula One cars are being made, Formula E mods exist, and so on.

I can tell you of some of the most fun I've had racing.

2010 V8 Supercars at Zolder. The car/track combo worked ideally, and both of these mods were made by completely different teams.

2011 ALMS at Sebring. Mixed class endurance racing. It's not easy, you have to negotiate through slow cars, and let fast cars through, and while racing another guy. It punishes mistakes, in a predictable way. This isn't F1 2012, it feels great.

2012 Indycar at Nazareth. Close, wheel to wheel racing without any AI derps. I think this is where the AI shows what it can do the most. Despite the high speeds, the AI works very well. No sudden giving up on moves and single file racing, no jumpy over excitement that inevitably leads to a 10 car pile up, it feels (and looks) like a real race.

Overall, I'd give rFactor an 8.5 out of 10. It's fun, but it's not the ultimate racing sim, at least not nowadays. Soon enough, rFactor 2 will come to Steam, and once the modding community starts doing what it does best, lets just say I have high hopes for ISI.


UPDATE: Being such an old game, this can be a real pain to configure modern wheels with. I use a ThrustMaster T150, and to set it up you have to change the settings with the wheel completely, and dig into the config files to reconfigure how steering works, and find FFB plugins to make the force feedback feel decent or just exist. These problems don't exist with other, more modern games that use wheels.

reviewText: Don't let the fact that this game is nearly 10 years old steer you away.  This game is fantastic and runs smooth across triple screens at 5358x1080 on my 580gtx at a consistent 60fps with a 50 car field.  It looks fantastic for any age and delivers way more realism in terms of experience than anything on consoles for less than 10 bucks.  Plus you can mod in 3,600 vehicles at 725 tracks overnight in one download with the auto-updater from our friends at Bockbierbude.   Amazing!\n\nTips: Set process affinity for all cores to on, make sure you run in high performance mode power plan, set nvidia to high perfomance modes and use vsync and triple buffering to get rid of stuttering if you see it.

reviewText:
I admit GSCE is my favourite sim, but I bought the standalone DVD verison of rFactor 1 many years ago and I decided to buy this old favourite now it is on Steam.

Reasons:
It's very good for a blast in the career mode, with earnings, fines, and purchasable upgrades, which GSCE does not have.

Also, it is a very moddable platform, and as many of the tracks share some original files with GSCE, such as AIWs, I can use the available ISI Dev tools to edit track paths and test them in this game, and use them in both.

I own rF2 & have tried the Assetto Corsa demo, & for me, they may be the sims of the future but they still have a way to go before they are the full package, so in the meantime, there is strong life left in the Gmotor engine, and with so many mods available, there is excellent value in GSCE and rFactor, or even both of them.

Finally, there's great performance even if you have a lesser powered pc.

reviewText:
Conclusion first:
I recommend rFactor to people who don't mind dated graphics and who know computers pretty well and are fine with all the trouble finding mods all over the internet and installing the mods. Search for some rFactor video on Youtube. If you can't stand the graphics, or if you want a game that has great content out-of-the-box, stay away from rFactor.

Although this sim has been out for many years, and it looks dated and starts to show its age in many aspects, and although I started sim racing from Assetto Corsa and Project Cars with much much better graphics, rFactor has taken up more and more of my sim racing time. It is a pretty solid mod platform and a solid sim racing game in general. I would recommend this game to anyone who's not too concerned about graphics and wants a racing sim with lots of contents. In fact on some tracks rFactor on my machine looks better and more impressive than its sequel rF2.

Pros:
1. Lots of mods providing almost anything you want with car racing. Lots of cars and tracks avaiable for download on various websites.
2. The handling of cars is quite natural. Of course how good a car drives highly depends on the quality of the mod, but generally speaking if you follow other people's suggestions you can get pretty decent experience.
3. The racing aspect of the game is solid. AI is pretty good providing nice battles, you get endurance features, and you can make your own championship or use what other people have made.

Cons:
1. Very dated look and graphics. It offers day/night transition but it looks pretty bad.
2. Championship mode feels very basic and there's no added feature to give you extra sense of achievement (such as a splash screen at the end to show the podium etc.).
3. Your experience with the game highly depends on the quality of mods. In fact I think it depends on the mods way too much. The base content is very very weak.
4. It is a PITA to find good mods and install them. Sometimes it's very hard to find a working download link because the mod might be old, and it's very hard to keep track of all the versions of the mods. Unlike the convenient rF2 Steam workshop implementation, the rF1 mod sites are very messy. Some mods screws up shared files of the game and breaks other mods, and some mod developers make unnecessary installation executable rather than just a compressed file to deploy their mod.
5. The road car side of this game is very, very limited. Even you go around the Internet and find all the good road car mods, it still feels very weak. Yes I know there is a Shift Street mod which is NFS Shift series rip-off but nearly all the cars have terrible handling and generally do not feel like the real thing.

Mods that I enjoy:
1. Enduracers' endurance mod. I particularly like the Flat6 series.
2. HistoX GT and Touring mod. This mod requires you having GT Legends, and the installation guide is convoluted. But as soon as you get it working almost every car is a blast to drive.

I think I'll probably give rFactor something like a 8/10.

reviewText: rFactor is an amazing racing sim that holds up very well today since it was released in 2006. While the cars and tracks you start out with are decent, you can expand your choices by downloading some of the thousands of mods that add cars and tracks. Want to change Ayrton Senna's fate at Imola? Download the F1 1994 mod. Enjoy watching the IZOD IndyCar series and wish you were a driver? There are mods for that. Prefer slower-paced vehicles and touring cars? reviewText: The stock content certainly shows it's age, 10 years by now. However where rFactor really shines is in the mods, there is an unmatched amounts of mods for rFactor, literally thousands of track and car mods are available. You can find mods for almost every year of Formula 1 and racing series you haven't even heard of. While the graphics in those mods won't be able to compete with Project Cars and the like, they can still look really nice and detailed and often substantially better then the stock content.\n\nThe game might be old, but it's essentially a legend by now and it will take quite some more years before any other sim out there will get remotely close to matching what rFactor along with all it's mods can offer. This should be in the collection of any serious simracer.

reviewText:
I've played far more than 10.3 hours since I've had rFactor far longer than I've had the Steam Key.  Let's start with pros and cons.  It's rFactor-the swiss army knife of sim racing.  Don't like what it does, download something totally different for it and change the game completely.  Admittedly, the ISI content that comes with rFactor is not good when compared to what modders have done with the game.  If you don't download any mods then I'd imagine you'd pretty damn disappointed with rFactor.  If you download some mods, then you're going to enjoy it much more.  Some mods I'd recommend
-Enduracers
-Historic Touring Cars
-Cart Factor
-V8 Supercars Unleashed
-Formula E (having a blast with this at the moment)
-DRM Revival (loud old cars with too much horsepower)

As for tracks there are hundreds.  Some of my favorites include
-Any of the Australian tracks (Barbagello, Mt. Panorama, etc)
-Monza, Nordschleife, Hockenheim, etc

rFactor has great mods and tracks.  It's a lot of fun to try them out.  Sure you'll get some bad ones but you can't go wrong with any of the mods I listed above.  I'm sure there's a few I've left out but I'm sure you'll discover them on your own.  There are still mods being made for this and there's still about 100x as many mods for rFactor 1 as there are for rFactor 2.  At this point, rFactor 1 is  the better buy over rFactor 2 in my eyes.  Hope this review helps

reviewText:
rFactor 1 is pretty unique. This is mod support writ large, a build-your-own-racing-sim kit.

The stock content is, essentially, a placeholder for whatever mods you're going to drop into the game.

It's rough around the edges and tricky to get force feedback working with the fidelity of more modern games, but here you can find some obscure and wonderful racing experiences. Or, y'know, make some of your own.

reviewText:
rFactor is not a racing game; it's a thriving workshop and a way to experience virtually every single kind of motorsports in the world, first-hand.

rFactor is just like a Cabbage Patch Kid; everybody has a different kind of rF setup, and things can be added and removed at any time.
There are many different mods (virtually all of which are FREE!) that can expand rFactor to your very own personal liking and preference. Want to go racing on the bumpy concrete runways of Sebring? You can get that. But what's Sebring without sportscars? Try the EnduRacers and GTPC mods, and your wish will be granted. Also, many of these mods can be expanded even further (!) with all manner of extra skins, car packs and tracks.

It's not the best looking game out there, but for something made in 2005, it looks great. Some modders have even given these limitations the middle finger; even on high-mid graphics settings, some of these add-on cars and tracks look absolutely amazing. Also, it's a rare example of a highly-regarded modern game that DOESN'T need a NASA supercomputer to run. My PC is an absolute potato, but it still runs absolutely fine, even with as many as 63 cars on the track at the same time. (Maybe it's powered by GlaDOS technology?)

If you're looking for a great racing sim that can be easily added to, throw GTR2, Project CARS and Assetto Corsa out the window and get this. You won't regret it.

reviewText: At first I was a bit skeptical, there seemed to be no updates, it seemed a little outdated, and it didnt seemed like there were many people playing this at first. But when you actually play the game, you will find that the game is a really nice simulation and you can tell that not much attention was paid to the graphics, but to the actual simulation and thats what makes this game, what I feel, a true simulation

reviewText:
Ignore my played hours time, i bought the hard copy back in the day and to be honest this is still great fun. If you would rather have the experience over visuals this game is for you, remember this game is old, If not Assetto, PC will be more your thing.

This is one of the best modded racing games of all time, so loads of good quality content. However the price tag of £19 is a bit steep, i got this for less than £5 in the sale and it is definetely worth it if you can grab it in a good sale.

Multiplayer almost dead, you will be able to get a race on a server somewhere though. Single player not bad at all and fun.

Overall 8\10 if bought for under£5,stilll good fun

reviewText: Played the game a tone, many years ago.  And seems to hold up very well mechanically.  Graphicly, below average.  But that shouldn't hold you back.  The issue, as with most older games, is player population.  There is still a very large player base.  But they are split into pockets.  Team of drivers here, racing league there.  The main one I found still running a server is the BROS Meganes V2" server.  A simple google will find their page
recommended: and track downloads.\n\nThis takes me to the next point
hoursPlayed: the game comes with a few racing serieses.  The bulk of the cars come from player made MODs.  Back when the game was in is prime.  Hundreds
voteText: if not maybe thousands of racing cars could be found.  From DTM
helpfulPercent: Souped up racing semi trucks.  Super V8s
commentsCount: and so on.  Same goes for race tracks.  So many to pick from.\n\nWith rFactor 2 out
column16: most have prolly moved on.  But more then enough have stayed back
column17: or come back.  To keep the game alive.  And may stay alive for a considerable time still."

reviewText:
This game beats all the games like Gran Turismo, Project Cars, Forza Motosport 4,5 basically all of the sim racing games off the board easily. The game doesn't have so much to offer itself, but the mods are LIMITLESS. Like you can mod anything to the game! The realism of some tracks/maps is unreal due to GPS/Laser scanning.

PROS:
-Alot of content to download made by the community
-Still an active community.
-One of the most realistic sim racers of all time.
-Wheel Setup is perfect! (also supports the lower-end wheels)
-Leagues
-Project D 2.3.1 for the players who likes to watch forward from the sidewindows.

CONS:
-Graphics are outdated but it was released in 2007.
-Even though the wheel setup is perfect, I experienced some issues with my wheel. (The car didn't want to steer to the right sometimes even though I had default settings.) The game also thought my wheel was only 180 degrees MAX. But thats sorted now.

reviewText:
Rfactor is a great game, when it came out it was a massive gamechanger, sadly a moment that i missed however picking it up i realise that maybe i was a little too late.

The engine is solid, the stability is solid, there is content, there is a insane number of mods and they work, they work well.

Alas things things start to turn sour but its not the fault of the game, its that as time has gone by new players have entered the ring, the successor has blown the doors off this game, others have brought the engine and made better games with it.

In the end this game is truely awesome however its old and it shows in the looks and technical sides and it shows massively in FFB. It not worth its price, a 10 year old game for a niche market isnt be this price, SCE is slightly more expensive and is a lot more fleshed out. The so called next gen" sims like AC and RF2 have features this could only dream of.

Id consider this on a sale but in its beaten brutally by the competition currently."

reviewText: Just another one of thos racing games that if you approach a bend too fast the only thing that will happen is that you will go straight ahead instead of turning. No amount of steering or braking will alter your path, once it decides you were going too fast, it will continue to go in a straight line until you hit something or if there was enough room your speed slowly decreases to almost stopped. If you like uncontrollable car games, fantastic, buy it!

reviewText: I do not recommend that anyone pay good money for this sim.  Not only is it outdated, you will spend about 50% of your time dealing with controller issues.  I (try to) play this sim w/ my Logitech G27 setup, and there are constant bugs.  You might eventually get it right (if you're lucky), however it will eventually fail again.  Extremely frustrating.  I should also add that my system has no problem with Assetto Corsa, or The Crew, as other examples.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game, why ?
Because it is an absolute classic title , a must have for all simmers/gamers who love motorsport.
The game itself is pretty old , but with some tinkering/experimenting with the graphic settings rFactor stands up really well and looks really good for it's age, on modern hardware the game can be easily maxed out with great performance.

rFactor requires some time spent with force feedback options to find a config that suits your play style , pretty much the same as the graphic options, when you hit the optimum setting you will discover that rFactor delivers a very realistic and satisfying racing simulation.

Brilliant 10/10

reviewText:
you can trust me when i say this game is fantastic, because i have 500 hours plus on this.
here's why:
it can run on almost anything, even that toaster you mum gave you for your 9th birthday.
it has the most mods you will ever find in any racing game,
it is damn fun with the near-infinite mods you will find
it's actually pretty realistic for an old 2004 game.
if you wanted to, you can spend 5 seconds editing files, it is incredibly easy

but here is why not as well:
pretty expensive for an old 2004 game
has dated graphics, but does that matter?
it might not be as popular as you think.

tl;dr, it is for the older computer, and it works like a gem on it too
